'''Roberto Concina''' (3 November 1969 – 9 May 2017), known professionally as '''Robert Miles''', was an Italian record producer, composer, musician and DJ.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imorecords.co.uk/house-2/house-artists/robert-miles-biography |title=Robert Miles Biography |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120804090544/http://www.imorecords.co.uk/house-2/house-artists/robert-miles-biography/ |archive-date=4 August 2012 |work=[[IMO Records]] |access-date=29 March 2011}}</ref> His 1995 composition "[[Children (composition)|Children]]" sold more than 5 million copies and topped the charts worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7792079/robert-miles-children-classic-hit-remembrance|title=Robert Miles' 'Children' Was a Time-Blurring, Brain-Sticking Classic|last=Unterberger|first=Andrew|date=10 May 2017|website=[[billboard.com]]|access-date=19 May 2017}}</ref>

==Early life==
Robert Miles was born in [[Fleurier]], Switzerland, to Italian parents.<ref name="bbc">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-39869009|title=Robert Miles: DJ known for 1990s hit Children dies aged 47|work=BBC News|access-date=10 May 2017}}</ref>

Miles became proficient at playing the piano during his youth in [[Friuli]], Italy, in the small town of [[Fagagna]], where his family moved when he was young, and had been in the music scene since 1984. He worked as a DJ in some Italian [[Nightclub|clubs]] and private radio networks, and in 1990 he used his savings to establish his own recording studio and a [[Pirate radio|pirate radio station]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Candy|first=Darren|date=23 March 2013|title=Robert Miles Speaks To Addicted To Ibiza|url=http://www.addictedtoibiza.com/2013/03/23/robert-miles/|access-date=8 August 2020|website=Addicted to ibiza|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=10 May 2017|title=R.I.P. Robert Miles (1969-2017)|url=https://stack.com.au/music/r-i-p-robert-miles/|access-date=8 August 2020|website=STACK {{!}} JB Hi-Fi|language=en-AU}}</ref>

==Music career==
===1994–1997: Breakthrough and ''Dreamland''===
{{External media
| float  = right
| width  = 270px
| video1 = {{YouTube |id=CC5ca6Hsb2Q |title="Robert Miles - 'Children' (Dream Version)"}}
}}
In 1994, Miles wrote a [[Trance music|trance]] and [[Chill-out music|chill-out]] piece based on acoustic guitar chords and soft synthesizer effects, "[[Children (composition)|Children]]", which was later developed into a [[Dream trance|dream house]] song featuring a piano theme on top.<ref name="LarkinDM"/> The single picked up sales slowly, but within two weeks of its official release in 1995, it had sold more than 350,000 copies all over Europe and topped the [[Record chart|charts]] in many countries. The single received an unprecedented "Essential Tune of The Week" three weeks in a row on [[Pete Tong]]'s show, causing a furious bidding war. It was then signed to Deconstruction Records in the UK by Giles Goodman of Dynamik Music (who represented Platipus Records the initial UK licensee).<ref name="LarkinDM"/> After occupying the Euro Top 100 chart number 1 spot for thirteen consecutive weeks {{crossref|(see [[European Hot 100 Singles]])}}, by 1997, "Children" had sold more than five million copies worldwide. It earned Miles [[Music recording sales certification|platinum records]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifpi.org/content/section_news/plat1997.html |title=IFPI Awards 1997 |website=ifpi.org |access-date=1 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100814140923/http://www.ifpi.org/content/section_news/plat1997.html |archive-date=14 August 2010 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certifiedawards/search.aspx |title=BPI Awards 1997 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5mr0Evm3j?url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certifiedawards/search.aspx |date=17 January 2010 |website=Bpi.co.uk |archive-date=17 January 2010 |url-status=dead |access-date=1 November 2011}}</ref> in many countries, a [[Brit Awards|Brit Award]] (Robert Miles is, to date, October 2022, the only Italian artist who has received the award) as Best International Male Newcomer 1997,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brits.co.uk/history/shows/1997 |title=The BRITs 1997 |website=brits.co.uk |access-date=1 November 2011}}</ref> a World Music Award as World's Best Selling Male Newcomer,<ref name="LarkinDM"/> and various other awards.

Miles' next single was "[[Fable (Robert Miles song)|Fable]]".<ref name="LarkinDM"/> Part of this song was used in the theatrical trailer for the U.S. movie ''[[Ever After]]'' {{crossref|(see {{slink|Ever After|Trailer}})}} starring [[Drew Barrymore]] and [[Dougray Scott]]. His debut album ''[[Dreamland (Robert Miles album)|Dreamland]]'' was released on 7 June 1996 in Europe,<ref name="LarkinDM"/> and released in the United States about a month later. The album included a cover of "[[One and One (song)|One and One]]" featuring British singer Maria Nayler. This cover became very popular (it reached number 1 in the Euro Top 100 Singles Chart during the Christmas period and remained in the top spot for six consecutive weeks)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ki.informatik.uni-wuerzburg.de/~topsi/mtv1996/mtv_211296.html |title=MTV Top Euro Chart 1996 |website=ki.informatik.uni-wuerzburg.de |access-date=1 November 2011}}</ref> and was later released as a single in Europe and the U.S.

===1997–1998: ''23am''===
In November 1997, Miles released another track, "[[Freedom (Robert Miles song)|Freedom]]", which was one of the key tracks on his second album ''[[23am]]'',<ref name="LarkinDM"/> featuring vocals provided by [[Kathy Sledge]] of [[Sister Sledge]]. Containing a different feel from the previously more club-oriented ''Dreamland'', ''23am'' incorporated more lyrics-driven songs than its predecessor while maintaining Miles' trademark piano sound from the first album.<ref name="LarkinDM">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Virgin Encyclopedia of Dance Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Virgin Books]]|date=1998|edition=First|isbn=0-7535-0252-6|page=223}}</ref>

===1998–2002: Departure from label and ''Organik''===
After splitting from [[Deconstruction Records|Deconstruction]], [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]] and his former management in London, he set up his own [[independent record label]] [[Salt Records]] (stylised as S:alt Records, with S:alt being short for suitably:alternative) in 2001 and released his third album, ''[[Organik]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=1&cid=2 |title=Salt Records Discography |publisher=Salt Records |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425130410/http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=1&cid=2 |archive-date=25 April 2012 |access-date=1 November 2011}}</ref> featuring the new single "Paths" with vocals provided by [[Nina Miranda]] of [[Smoke City]]. Guests on the album included [[Trilok Gurtu]], [[Bill Laswell]] and [[Nitin Sawhney]]. Music from ''Organik'' was used on various [[Soundtrack|movie soundtracks]] such as ''[[The Bourne Identity (2002 film)|The Bourne Identity]]'', ''[[Derrida (film)|Derrida]]'', and ''[[City of Ghosts (2002 film)|City of Ghosts]]''. It was licensed to [[Narada Productions]]' Shakti Records label in the USA. In 2002, an album containing mainly [[remix]]es of songs found on ''Organik'' was released. The album, appropriately entitled ''[[Organik Remixes]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=1&cid=16 |title=Salt Records Discography |publisher=Salt Records |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509080543/http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=1&cid=16 |archive-date=9 May 2012 |access-date=1 November 2011}}</ref> contained remixes by the winners of the remixing contest held on Robert Miles's Web site, as well as remixes from well-known artists such as [[Future Sound of London]], [[Riton (musician)|Riton]], and Alexkid among others.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=RA ⟋ Electronic music online|url=https://ra.co/|access-date=18 January 2022|website=Resident Advisor|language=en}}</ref> The album also had one new track, "Bhairav", which featured the vocals of [[Amelia Cuni]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Organik Remixes - Robert Miles {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/organik-remixes-mw0000322629|language=en|access-date=19 January 2022}}</ref>

===2004–2005: ''Miles_Gurtu''===
In 2004, Miles released ''[[Miles Gurtu]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=3&cid=17 |title=Salt Records Discography |publisher=Salt Records |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515105258/http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=3&cid=17 |archive-date=15 May 2012}}</ref> his fourth album, which was a collaboration with percussionist [[Trilok Gurtu]] and included [[jazz]] and [[electronica]] elements. Also guesting on the album were [[Nitin Sawhney]], [[Jon Thorne]], Mike Patto and Paul Falloon.<ref name=":0" />

===2011–2012: ''Thirteen''===
Miles' fifth album, entitled ''[[Thirteen (Robert Miles album)|Thirteen]],''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=1&cid=65 |title=Salt Records Discography |publisher=Salt Records |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331060032/http://www.saltrecords.com/recordings/discography/?id=1&cid=65 |archive-date=31 March 2012 |access-date=7 October 2018}}</ref> was released worldwide on Salt Records in February 2011. For this album, Miles produced a blend of alternative and [[progressive rock]] with [[Ambient music|ambient]] and electronic soundscapes.<ref>{{Citation|title=Th1Rt3En - Robert Miles {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/th1rt3en-mw0002093465|language=en|access-date=19 January 2022}}</ref>

In 2012 Miles finished working on the soundtrack for the movie documentary ''The Turn of THIS Century'', directed by Peter Beyak and featuring the photography of [[Life Magazine]]. He founded a new FM and online alternative radio station, ''Open Lab'', broadcasting from [[Ibiza]], a project bringing together culture, arts, media, technology and innovation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://openlab.fm/about/what-is-openlab/openlab-is-an-ethos |title=Open Lab |website=openlab.fm |access-date=15 June 2017}}</ref>

==Death==
Miles died from cancer in Ibiza, Spain, on 9 May 2017 at the age of 47.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.24-horas.mx/fallece-el-dj-robert-miles-creador-del-tema-children-video/ |title=Fallece el Dj Robert Miles, creador del tema 'Children' |language=es |website=24 Horas |date=9 May 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510074311/http://www.24-horas.mx/fallece-el-dj-robert-miles-creador-del-tema-children-video/ |archive-date=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="bbc" />

Miles’ Open Lab station was taken off-air shortly afterwards, pending discussions on the future of the station.  After receiving many messages from people expressing dismay at the station's suspension, it was announced that the station would be returning soon in 2019, starting with a live radio stream in January 2019 and followed by a reboot to radio on 106.4 FM in Ibiza in April 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://openlab.fm/about/what-is-openlab/openlab-is-an-ethos |title=Open Lab |website=openlab.fm |access-date=28 May 2018}}</ref>
